nikomatsakis said:

kind of telling "rust contributors" a bit about the 2021 edition

and the process we are following
I think of the process as:
• We have some milestones by which things must be ready to be included
e.g., must have an RFC by this time, impl by that time, crater run by that time
• There is a spreadsheet where people can figure stuff out
• Come talk on #edition with questions or thoughts
As we said, I don't really see this as a "call for people to submit ideas"
But I do kind of want people to raise ideas if there is some long-standing thing we're missing
e.g., I still have to follow up on #edition > never type
That's fine. Sounds like a good idea. Let me rewrite the post then. When do you want to have this out?
next week sometime?

@rylev looks great!

Wondering if the three examples (prelude, capture rules, remove static mut) are the right ones to highlight like this. Especially removal of static mut is still a bit unclear, and might not happen. The examples mentioned under 'Other' on the other hand are most definitely going to happen (the panic stuff is already implemented and already has an active lint, and cargo's resolver = "2" is also already usable). So it might make sense to swap some of the examples around.

Maybe resolver = "2" is the best one since it's really just a new default. The entire feature is available on all editions, it just changes the default on the new edition. This explains nicely the principle of wanting to give all editions the features if we can and limiting edition differences to the absolute bare minimum.
@rylev will read now!
I added one note
As we approach these deadlines, we'll be narrowing down the list of proposed changes to those items that have made active progress.
and tweaked a few other minor things
but overall, I like it!
I think it would be good to emphasize for the not-yet-approved changes (e.g., in particular prelude) that this blog post is not an indicator of decisions being made
I wouldn't want people to think we're bypassing the RFC consensus process

It is no longer possible to introduce features for inclusion in Rust 2021 which have not yet been discussed at all. Of course, anyone can already open an issue or RFC for a change to be included in the next edition of Rust following Rust 2021.

I would like to avoid people discussing things for edition-next right now, to be honest, since it seems less urgent and I want us to get 2021 buttoned down before we get into that too much.

Maybe something like: "There's not sufficient bandwidth to consider ideas that haven't been discussed at all yet, but we're excited to hear them. That said, our bandwidth is limited, and we want to focus on the 2021 edition for the next few months at least, so please know that the teams are unlikely to be able to give new proposals for future editions consideration in the next month or two at least"

I don't think we should say in the blog post that that's something we're considering doing, when it's not close to the point where we should commit to that.
Edition 2051: we might finally deprecate static mut this year
